dcterms_description.literal: Standards in Historical Thinking

children.text: Standard 1: Chronological Thinking

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 1: Chronological Thinking

children.text: STANDARD 1<br /> The student thinks chronologically:

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 1<br /> The student thinks chronologically:

children.text: A. Distinguish between past, present, and future time.

dcterms_description.literal: A. Distinguish between past, present, and future time.

children.text: B. Identify the temporal structure of a historical narrative or story: its beginning, middle, and end (the latter defined as the outcome of a particular beginning).

dcterms_description.literal: B. Identify the temporal structure of a historical narrative or story: its beginning, middle, and end (the latter defined as the outcome of a particular beginning).

children.text: C. Establish temporal order in constructing their [students'] own historical narratives: working forward from some beginning through its development, to some end or outcome; working backward from some issue, problem, or event to explain its origins and its development over time.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Establish temporal order in constructing their [students'] own historical narratives: working forward from some beginning through its development, to some end or outcome; working backward from some issue, problem, or event to explain its origins and its development over time.

children.text: D. Measure and calculate calendar time by days, weeks, months, years, decades, centuries.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Measure and calculate calendar time by days, weeks, months, years, decades, centuries.

children.text: E. Interpret data presented in timelines.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Interpret data presented in timelines.

children.text: F. Create timelines by designating appropriate equidistant intervals of time and recording events according to the temporal order in which they occurred.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Create timelines by designating appropriate equidistant intervals of time and recording events according to the temporal order in which they occurred.

children.text: G. Explain change and continuity over time.

dcterms_description.literal: G. Explain change and continuity over time.

children.text: D. Measure and calculate calendar time by days, weeks, months, years, decades, centuriesand millennia, from fixed points of the calendar system: BC (before Christ) and AD (Anno Domini, "in the year of our Lord") in the Gregorian calendar and the contemporary secular designation for these same dates, BCE (before the Common Era) and CE (in the Common Era); and compare with the fixed points of other calendar systems such as the Roman (753 BC, the founding of the city of Rome) and the Muslim (622 AD, the hegira).

dcterms_description.literal: D. Measure and calculate calendar time by days, weeks, months, years, decades, centuriesand millennia, from fixed points of the calendar system: BC (before Christ) and AD (Anno Domini, "in the year of our Lord") in the Gregorian calendar and the contemporary secular designation for these same dates, BCE (before the Common Era) and CE (in the Common Era); and compare with the fixed points of other calendar systems such as the Roman (753 BC, the founding of the city of Rome) and the Muslim (622 AD, the hegira).

children.text: E. Interpret data presented in timelines by designating appropriate equidistant intervals of time and recording events according to the temporal order in which they occurred.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Interpret data presented in timelines by designating appropriate equidistant intervals of time and recording events according to the temporal order in which they occurred.

children.text: F. Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration in which historical developments have unfolded, and apply them to explain historical continuity and change.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration in which historical developments have unfolded, and apply them to explain historical continuity and change.

children.text: G. Compare alternative models for periodization by identifying the organizing principles on which each is based.

dcterms_description.literal: G. Compare alternative models for periodization by identifying the organizing principles on which each is based.

children.text: Standard 2: Historical Comprehension

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 2: Historical Comprehension

children.text: STANDARD 2<br /> The student comprehends a variety of historical sources:

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 2<br /> The student comprehends a variety of historical sources:

children.text: A. Identify the author or source of the historical document or narrative.

dcterms_description.literal: A. Identify the author or source of the historical document or narrative.

children.text: B. Reconstruct the literal meaning of a historical passage by identifying who was involved, what happened, where it happened, what events led to these developments, and what consequences or outcomes followed.

dcterms_description.literal: B. Reconstruct the literal meaning of a historical passage by identifying who was involved, what happened, where it happened, what events led to these developments, and what consequences or outcomes followed.

children.text: C. Identify the central question(s) the historical narrative addresses and the purpose, perspective, or point of view from which it has been constructed.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Identify the central question(s) the historical narrative addresses and the purpose, perspective, or point of view from which it has been constructed.

children.text: D. Read historical narratives imaginatively, taking into account (a) the historical context in which the event unfolded-the values, outlook, crises, options, and contingencies of that time and place; and (b) what the narrative reveals of the humanity of the individuals involved-their probable motives, hopes, fears, strengths, and weaknesses.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Read historical narratives imaginatively, taking into account (a) the historical context in which the event unfolded-the values, outlook, crises, options, and contingencies of that time and place; and (b) what the narrative reveals of the humanity of the individuals involved-their probable motives, hopes, fears, strengths, and weaknesses.

children.text: E. Appreciate historical perspectives--the ability (a) to describe the past on its own terms, through the eyes and experiences of those who were there, as revealed through their literature, diaries, letters, arts, artifacts, and the like; and (b) to avoid "present-mindedness," judging the past solely in terms of present-day norms and values.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Appreciate historical perspectives--the ability (a) to describe the past on its own terms, through the eyes and experiences of those who were there, as revealed through their literature, diaries, letters, arts, artifacts, and the like; and (b) to avoid "present-mindedness," judging the past solely in terms of present-day norms and values.

children.text: F. Draw upon data in historical maps in order to obtain or clarify information on the geographic setting in which the historical event occurred, its relative and absolute location, the distances and directions involved, the natural and man-made features of the place, and critical relationships in the spatial distributions of those features and the historical event occurring there.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Draw upon data in historical maps in order to obtain or clarify information on the geographic setting in which the historical event occurred, its relative and absolute location, the distances and directions involved, the natural and man-made features of the place, and critical relationships in the spatial distributions of those features and the historical event occurring there.

children.text: G. Draw upon the visual and mathematical data presented in graphs, including charts, tables, pie and bar graphs, flow charts, Venn diagrams, and other graphic organizers to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

dcterms_description.literal: G. Draw upon the visual and mathematical data presented in graphs, including charts, tables, pie and bar graphs, flow charts, Venn diagrams, and other graphic organizers to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

children.text: H. Draw upon the visual data presented in photographs, paintings, cartoons, and architectural drawings in order to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

dcterms_description.literal: H. Draw upon the visual data presented in photographs, paintings, cartoons, and architectural drawings in order to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

children.text: D. Differentiate between historical facts and historical interpretations but acknowledge that the two are related; that the facts the historian reports are selected and reflect therefore the historian's judgement of what is most significant about the past.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Differentiate between historical facts and historical interpretations but acknowledge that the two are related; that the facts the historian reports are selected and reflect therefore the historian's judgement of what is most significant about the past.

children.text: E. Read historical narratives imaginatively, taking into account what the narrative reveals of the humanity of the individuals and groups involved--their probable values, outlook, motives, hopes, fears, strengths, and weaknesses.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Read historical narratives imaginatively, taking into account what the narrative reveals of the humanity of the individuals and groups involved--their probable values, outlook, motives, hopes, fears, strengths, and weaknesses.

children.text: F. Appreciate historical perspectives--the ability (a) describing the past on its own terms, through the eyes and experiences of those who were there, as revealed through their literature, diaries, letters, debates, arts, artifacts, and the like; (b) considering the historical context in which the event unfolded--the values, outlook, options, and contingencies of that time and place; and (c) avoiding "present-mindedness," judging the past solely in terms of present-day norms and values.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Appreciate historical perspectives--the ability (a) describing the past on its own terms, through the eyes and experiences of those who were there, as revealed through their literature, diaries, letters, debates, arts, artifacts, and the like; (b) considering the historical context in which the event unfolded--the values, outlook, options, and contingencies of that time and place; and (c) avoiding "present-mindedness," judging the past solely in terms of present-day norms and values.

children.text: G. Draw upon data in historical maps in order to obtain or clarify information on the geographic setting in which the historical event occurred, its relative and absolute location, the distances and directions involved, the natural and man-made features of the place, and critical relationships in the spatial distributions of those features and the historical event occurring there.

dcterms_description.literal: G. Draw upon data in historical maps in order to obtain or clarify information on the geographic setting in which the historical event occurred, its relative and absolute location, the distances and directions involved, the natural and man-made features of the place, and critical relationships in the spatial distributions of those features and the historical event occurring there.

children.text: H. Utilize visual and mathematical data presented in graphs, including charts, tables, pie and bar graphs, flow charts, Venn diagrams, and other graphic organizers to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

dcterms_description.literal: H. Utilize visual and mathematical data presented in graphs, including charts, tables, pie and bar graphs, flow charts, Venn diagrams, and other graphic organizers to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

children.text: I. Draw upon the visual, literary, and musical sources including: (a) photographs, paintings, cartoons, and architectural drawings; (b) novels, poetry, and plays; and, (c) folk, popular and classical music, to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

dcterms_description.literal: I. Draw upon the visual, literary, and musical sources including: (a) photographs, paintings, cartoons, and architectural drawings; (b) novels, poetry, and plays; and, (c) folk, popular and classical music, to clarify, illustrate, or elaborate upon information presented in the historical narrative.

children.text: Standard 3: Historical Analysis and Interpretation

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 3: Historical Analysis and Interpretation

children.text: STANDARD 3<br /> The student engages in historical analysis and interpretation:

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 3<br /> The student engages in historical analysis and interpretation:

children.text: A. Formulate questions to focus their inquiry and analysis.

dcterms_description.literal: A. Formulate questions to focus their inquiry and analysis.

children.text: B. Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas, values, personalities, behaviors, and institutions by identifying likenesses and differences.

dcterms_description.literal: B. Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas, values, personalities, behaviors, and institutions by identifying likenesses and differences.

children.text: C. Analyze historical fiction on such criteria as the accuracy of the story's historical details and sequence of events; and the point of view or interpretation presented by the author through the words, actions, and descriptions of the characters and events in the story.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Analyze historical fiction on such criteria as the accuracy of the story's historical details and sequence of events; and the point of view or interpretation presented by the author through the words, actions, and descriptions of the characters and events in the story.

children.text: D. Distinguish fact and fiction by comparing documentary sources on historical figures and events with the fictional characters and events included in the story and its illustrations.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Distinguish fact and fiction by comparing documentary sources on historical figures and events with the fictional characters and events included in the story and its illustrations.

children.text: E. Compare different stories about a historical figure, era, or event and analyze the different portrayals or perspectives they present.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Compare different stories about a historical figure, era, or event and analyze the different portrayals or perspectives they present.

children.text: F. Analyze illustrations in historical stories for the information they reveal and compare with historic sites, museum artifacts, historical photos, and other documents to judge their accuracy.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Analyze illustrations in historical stories for the information they reveal and compare with historic sites, museum artifacts, historical photos, and other documents to judge their accuracy.

children.text: G. Consider multiple perspectives in the records of human experience by demonstrating how their differing motives, beliefs, interests, hopes, and fears influenced individual and group behaviors.

dcterms_description.literal: G. Consider multiple perspectives in the records of human experience by demonstrating how their differing motives, beliefs, interests, hopes, and fears influenced individual and group behaviors.

children.text: H. Explain causes in analyzing historical actions, including (a) the importance of the individual in history, of human will, intellect, and character; (b) the influence of ideas, human interests, and beliefs; and (c) the role of chance, the accidental, and the irrational.

dcterms_description.literal: H. Explain causes in analyzing historical actions, including (a) the importance of the individual in history, of human will, intellect, and character; (b) the influence of ideas, human interests, and beliefs; and (c) the role of chance, the accidental, and the irrational.

children.text: I. Challenge arguments of historical inevitability by giving examples of how different choices could have led to different consequences.

dcterms_description.literal: I. Challenge arguments of historical inevitability by giving examples of how different choices could have led to different consequences.

children.text: J. Hypothesize the influence of the past, including both the limitations and opportunities made possible by past decisions.

dcterms_description.literal: J. Hypothesize the influence of the past, including both the limitations and opportunities made possible by past decisions.

children.text: A. Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas, values, personalities, behaviors, and institutions by identifying likenesses and differences.

dcterms_description.literal: A. Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas, values, personalities, behaviors, and institutions by identifying likenesses and differences.

children.text: B. Consider multiple perspectives of various peoples in the past by demonstrating their differing motives, beliefs, interests, hopes, and fears.

dcterms_description.literal: B. Consider multiple perspectives of various peoples in the past by demonstrating their differing motives, beliefs, interests, hopes, and fears.

children.text: C. Analyze cause-and-effect relationships bearing in mind multiple causation including (a) the importance of the individual in history; (b) the influence of ideas, human interests, and beliefs; and (c) the role of chance, the accidental and the irrational.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Analyze cause-and-effect relationships bearing in mind multiple causation including (a) the importance of the individual in history; (b) the influence of ideas, human interests, and beliefs; and (c) the role of chance, the accidental and the irrational.

children.text: D. Draw comparisons across eras and regions in order to define enduring issues as well as large-scale or long-term developments that transcend regional and temporal boundaries.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Draw comparisons across eras and regions in order to define enduring issues as well as large-scale or long-term developments that transcend regional and temporal boundaries.

children.text: E. Distinguish between unsupported expressions of opinion and informed hypotheses grounded in historical evidence.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Distinguish between unsupported expressions of opinion and informed hypotheses grounded in historical evidence.

children.text: F. Compare competing historical narratives.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Compare competing historical narratives.

children.text: G. Challenge arguments of historical inevitability by formulating examples of historical contingency, of how different choices could have led to different consequences.

dcterms_description.literal: G. Challenge arguments of historical inevitability by formulating examples of historical contingency, of how different choices could have led to different consequences.

children.text: H. Hold interpretations of history as tentative, subject to changes as new information is uncovered, new voices heard, and new interpretations broached.

dcterms_description.literal: H. Hold interpretations of history as tentative, subject to changes as new information is uncovered, new voices heard, and new interpretations broached.

children.text: I. Evaluate major debates among historians concerning alternative interpretations of the past.

dcterms_description.literal: I. Evaluate major debates among historians concerning alternative interpretations of the past.

children.text: Standard 4: Historical Research Capabilities

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 4: Historical Research Capabilities

children.text: STANDARD 4<br /> The student conducts historical research:

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 4<br /> The student conducts historical research:

children.text: A. Formulate historical questions from encounters with historical documents, eyewitness accounts, letters, diaries, artifacts, photos, historical sites, art, architecture, and other records from the past.

dcterms_description.literal: A. Formulate historical questions from encounters with historical documents, eyewitness accounts, letters, diaries, artifacts, photos, historical sites, art, architecture, and other records from the past.

children.text: B. Obtain historical data from a variety of sources, including: library and museum collections, historic sites, historical photos, journals, diaries, eyewitness accounts, newspapers, and the like; documentary films; and so on.

dcterms_description.literal: B. Obtain historical data from a variety of sources, including: library and museum collections, historic sites, historical photos, journals, diaries, eyewitness accounts, newspapers, and the like; documentary films; and so on.

children.text: C. Interrogate historical data by determining by whom and when it was created; testing the data source for its credibility, authority and authenticity; and detecting and evaluating bias, distortion, and propaganda by omission, suppression, or invention of facts.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Interrogate historical data by determining by whom and when it was created; testing the data source for its credibility, authority and authenticity; and detecting and evaluating bias, distortion, and propaganda by omission, suppression, or invention of facts.

children.text: D. Marshal needed information of the time and place in order to construct a story, explanation, or historical narrative.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Marshal needed information of the time and place in order to construct a story, explanation, or historical narrative.

children.text: B. Obtain historical data from a variety of sources, including: library and museum collections, historic sites, historical photos, journals, diaries, eyewitness accounts, newspapers, and the like; documentary films, oral testimony from living witnesses, censuses, tax records, city directories, statistical compilations, and economic indicators.

dcterms_description.literal: B. Obtain historical data from a variety of sources, including: library and museum collections, historic sites, historical photos, journals, diaries, eyewitness accounts, newspapers, and the like; documentary films, oral testimony from living witnesses, censuses, tax records, city directories, statistical compilations, and economic indicators.

children.text: C. Interrogate historical data by uncovering the social, political, and economic context in which it was created; testing the data source for its credibility, authority, authenticity, internal consistency and completeness; and detecting and evaluating bias, distortion, and propaganda by omission, suppression, or invention of facts.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Interrogate historical data by uncovering the social, political, and economic context in which it was created; testing the data source for its credibility, authority, authenticity, internal consistency and completeness; and detecting and evaluating bias, distortion, and propaganda by omission, suppression, or invention of facts.

children.text: D. Identify the gaps in the available records and marshal contextual knowledge and perspectives of the time and place in order to elaborate imaginatively upon the evidence, fill in the gaps deductively, and construct a sound historical interpretation.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Identify the gaps in the available records and marshal contextual knowledge and perspectives of the time and place in order to elaborate imaginatively upon the evidence, fill in the gaps deductively, and construct a sound historical interpretation.

children.text: E. Employ quantitative analysis in order to explore such topics as changes in family size and composition, migration patterns, wealth distribution, and changes in the economy.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Employ quantitative analysis in order to explore such topics as changes in family size and composition, migration patterns, wealth distribution, and changes in the economy.

children.text: F. Support interpretations with historical evidence in order to construct closely reasoned arguments rather than facile opinions.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Support interpretations with historical evidence in order to construct closely reasoned arguments rather than facile opinions.

children.text: Standard 5: Historical Issues-Analysis and Decision-Making

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 5: Historical Issues-Analysis and Decision-Making

children.text: STANDARD 5<br /> The student engages in historical issues-analysis and decision-making:

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 5<br /> The student engages in historical issues-analysis and decision-making:

children.text: A. Identify problems and dilemmas confronting people in historical stories, myths, legends, and fables, and in the history of their school, community, state, nation, and the world.

dcterms_description.literal: A. Identify problems and dilemmas confronting people in historical stories, myths, legends, and fables, and in the history of their school, community, state, nation, and the world.

children.text: B. Analyze the interests, values, and points of view of those involved in the dilemma or problem situation.

dcterms_description.literal: B. Analyze the interests, values, and points of view of those involved in the dilemma or problem situation.

children.text: C. Identify causes of the problem or dilemma.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Identify causes of the problem or dilemma.

children.text: D. Propose alternative ways of resolving the problem or dilemma and evaluate each in terms of ethical consideration (is it fair? just?), the interest of the different people involved, and the likely consequences of each proposal.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Propose alternative ways of resolving the problem or dilemma and evaluate each in terms of ethical consideration (is it fair? just?), the interest of the different people involved, and the likely consequences of each proposal.

children.text: E. Formulate a position or course of action on an issue by identifying the nature of the problem, analyzing the underlying factors contributing to the problem, and choosing a plausible solution from a choice of carefully evaluated options.

dcterms_description.literal: E. Formulate a position or course of action on an issue by identifying the nature of the problem, analyzing the underlying factors contributing to the problem, and choosing a plausible solution from a choice of carefully evaluated options.

children.text: F. Identify the solution chosen by characters in the story or in the historical situation; or, recommend a course of action themselves.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Identify the solution chosen by characters in the story or in the historical situation; or, recommend a course of action themselves.

children.text: G. Evaluate the consequences of the actions taken.

dcterms_description.literal: G. Evaluate the consequences of the actions taken.

children.text: A. Identify issues and problems in the past and analyze the interests, values, perspectives, and points of view of those involved in the situation.

dcterms_description.literal: A. Identify issues and problems in the past and analyze the interests, values, perspectives, and points of view of those involved in the situation.

children.text: B. Marshal evidence of antecedent circumstances and current factors contributing to contemporary problems and alternative courses of action.

dcterms_description.literal: B. Marshal evidence of antecedent circumstances and current factors contributing to contemporary problems and alternative courses of action.

children.text: C. Identify relevant historical antecedents and differentiate from those that are inappropriate and irrelevant to contemporary issues.

dcterms_description.literal: C. Identify relevant historical antecedents and differentiate from those that are inappropriate and irrelevant to contemporary issues.

children.text: D. Evaluate alternative courses of action, keeping in mind the information available at the time, in terms of ethical considerations, the interests of those affected by the decision, and the long- and short-term consequences of each.

dcterms_description.literal: D. Evaluate alternative courses of action, keeping in mind the information available at the time, in terms of ethical considerations, the interests of those affected by the decision, and the long- and short-term consequences of each.

children.text: F. Evaluate the implementation of a decision by analyzing the interests it served; estimating the position, power, and priority of each player involved; assessing the ethical dimensions of the decision; and evaluating its costs and benefits from a variety of perspectives.

dcterms_description.literal: F. Evaluate the implementation of a decision by analyzing the interests it served; estimating the position, power, and priority of each player involved; assessing the ethical dimensions of the decision; and evaluating its costs and benefits from a variety of perspectives.

text: Standards in History for Grades K-4 (Content Standards)

dcterms_description.literal: Standards in History for Grades K-4 (Content Standards)

children.text: Topic 1: Living and Working Together in Families and Communities, Now and Long Ago

dcterms_description.literal: Topic 1: Living and Working Together in Families and Communities, Now and Long Ago

children.text: STANDARD 1<br /> Family life now and in the recent past; family life in various places long ago.

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 1<br /> Family life now and in the recent past; family life in various places long ago.

children.text: Standard 1A: The student understands family life now and in the recent past; family life in various places long ago.

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 1A: The student understands family life now and in the recent past; family life in various places long ago.

children.text: Investigate a family history for at least two generations, identifying various members and their connections in order to construct a timeline. (Teachers should help students understand that families are people from whom they receive love and support. Understanding that many students are raised in nontraditional family structures--i.e., single-parent families, foster homes, guardians raising children--teachers must be sensitive and protect family privacy.) [Establish temporal order]

dcterms_description.literal: Investigate a family history for at least two generations, identifying various members and their connections in order to construct a timeline. (Teachers should help students understand that families are people from whom they receive love and support. Understanding that many students are raised in nontraditional family structures--i.e., single-parent families, foster homes, guardians raising children--teachers must be sensitive and protect family privacy.) [Establish temporal order]

children.text: From data gathered through family artifacts, photos, and interviews with older relatives and/or other people who play a significant part in a student's life, draw possible conclusions about roles, jobs, schooling experiences, and other aspects of family life in the recent past. [Draw upon historical and visual data]

dcterms_description.literal: From data gathered through family artifacts, photos, and interviews with older relatives and/or other people who play a significant part in a student's life, draw possible conclusions about roles, jobs, schooling experiences, and other aspects of family life in the recent past. [Draw upon historical and visual data]

children.text: For various cultures represented in the classroom, compare and contrast family life now with family life over time and between various cultures and consider such things as communication, technology, homes, transportation, recreation, school and cultural traditions. [Distinguish between past and present]

dcterms_description.literal: For various cultures represented in the classroom, compare and contrast family life now with family life over time and between various cultures and consider such things as communication, technology, homes, transportation, recreation, school and cultural traditions. [Distinguish between past and present]

children.text: Examine and formulate questions about early records, diaries, family photographs, artifacts, and architectural drawings obtained through a local newspaper or historical society in order to describe family life in their local community or state long ago. [Formulate historical questions]

dcterms_description.literal: Examine and formulate questions about early records, diaries, family photographs, artifacts, and architectural drawings obtained through a local newspaper or historical society in order to describe family life in their local community or state long ago. [Formulate historical questions]

children.text: Compare and contrast family life now with family life in the local community or state long ago by considering such things as roles, jobs, communication, technology, style of homes, transportation, schools, religious observances, and cultural traditions. [Compare and contrast]

dcterms_description.literal: Compare and contrast family life now with family life in the local community or state long ago by considering such things as roles, jobs, communication, technology, style of homes, transportation, schools, religious observances, and cultural traditions. [Compare and contrast]

children.text: Standard 1B: The student understands the different ways people of diverse racial, religious, and ethnic groups, and of various national origins have transmitted their beliefs and values.

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 1B: The student understands the different ways people of diverse racial, religious, and ethnic groups, and of various national origins have transmitted their beliefs and values.

children.text: Explain the ways that families long ago expressed and transmitted their beliefs and values through oral traditions, literature, songs, art, religion, community celebrations, mementos, food, and language. [Obtain historical data]

dcterms_description.literal: Explain the ways that families long ago expressed and transmitted their beliefs and values through oral traditions, literature, songs, art, religion, community celebrations, mementos, food, and language. [Obtain historical data]

children.text: Compare the dreams and ideals that people from various groups have sought, some of the problems they encountered in realizing their dreams, and the sources of strength and determination that families drew upon and shared. [Compare and contrast]

dcterms_description.literal: Compare the dreams and ideals that people from various groups have sought, some of the problems they encountered in realizing their dreams, and the sources of strength and determination that families drew upon and shared. [Compare and contrast]

children.text: STANDARD 2<br /> The history of students' own local community and how communities in North America varied long ago.

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 2<br /> The history of students' own local community and how communities in North America varied long ago.

children.text: Standard 2A: The student understands the history of his or her local community.

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 2A: The student understands the history of his or her local community.

children.text: Create a historical narrative about the history of his or her local community from data gathered from local residents, records found in early newspapers, historical documents and photographs, and artifacts and other data found in local museums and historical societies. [Construct a historical narrative]

dcterms_description.literal: Create a historical narrative about the history of his or her local community from data gathered from local residents, records found in early newspapers, historical documents and photographs, and artifacts and other data found in local museums and historical societies. [Construct a historical narrative]

children.text: From resources that are available in the local community, record changes that have occurred in goods and services over time. [Establish temporal order]

dcterms_description.literal: From resources that are available in the local community, record changes that have occurred in goods and services over time. [Establish temporal order]

children.text: Describe local community life long ago, including jobs, schooling, transportation, communication, religious observances, and recreation. [Obtain historical data]

dcterms_description.literal: Describe local community life long ago, including jobs, schooling, transportation, communication, religious observances, and recreation. [Obtain historical data]

children.text: Interpret population data from historical and current maps, charts, graphs, and census tables in order to make generalizations about the changing size and makeup of the local community. [Interrogate the data]

dcterms_description.literal: Interpret population data from historical and current maps, charts, graphs, and census tables in order to make generalizations about the changing size and makeup of the local community. [Interrogate the data]

children.text: Examine local architecture and landscape to compare changes in function and appearance over time. [Draw upon visual data]

dcterms_description.literal: Examine local architecture and landscape to compare changes in function and appearance over time. [Draw upon visual data]

dcterms_description.literal: Topic 3: The History of the United States: Democratic Principles and Values and the People from Many Cultures Who Contributed to Its Cultural, Economic, and Political Heritage

children.text: STANDARD 4<br /> How democratic values came to be, and how they have been exemplified by people, events, and symbols.

dcterms_description.literal: STANDARD 4<br /> How democratic values came to be, and how they have been exemplified by people, events, and symbols.

children.text: Standard 4A: Demonstrate understanding of how the United States government was formed and of the nation's basic democratic principles set forth in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 4A: Demonstrate understanding of how the United States government was formed and of the nation's basic democratic principles set forth in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

children.text: Explain that the U.S. government was formed by English colonists who fought for independence from England. [Explain causes and consequences]

dcterms_description.literal: Explain that the U.S. government was formed by English colonists who fought for independence from England. [Explain causes and consequences]

children.text: Identify and explain the basic principles that Americans set forth in the documents that declared the nation's independence from England (the Declaration of Independence) and that created the new nation's government (U.S. Constitution). [Demonstrate and explain the influence of ideas]

dcterms_description.literal: Identify and explain the basic principles that Americans set forth in the documents that declared the nation's independence from England (the Declaration of Independence) and that created the new nation's government (U.S. Constitution). [Demonstrate and explain the influence of ideas]

children.text: Explain the importance of the basic principles of American democracy that unify us as a nation: our individual rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness; responsibility for the common good; equality of opportunity and equal protection of the law; freedom of speech and religion; majority rule with protection for minority rights; and limitations on government, with power held by the people and delegated by them to their elected officials who are responsible to those who elected them to office. [Demonstrate and explain the influence of ideas]

dcterms_description.literal: Explain the importance of the basic principles of American democracy that unify us as a nation: our individual rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness; responsibility for the common good; equality of opportunity and equal protection of the law; freedom of speech and religion; majority rule with protection for minority rights; and limitations on government, with power held by the people and delegated by them to their elected officials who are responsible to those who elected them to office. [Demonstrate and explain the influence of ideas]

children.text: Analyze how over the last 200 years individuals and groups in American society have struggled to achieve the liberties and equality promised in the principles of American democracy. [Analyze continuity and change ]

dcterms_description.literal: Analyze how over the last 200 years individuals and groups in American society have struggled to achieve the liberties and equality promised in the principles of American democracy. [Analyze continuity and change ]

dcterms_description.literal: Standard 4B: Demonstrate understanding of ordinary people who have exemplified values and principles of American democracy.
